en.Slide 1: Let's see how we can define upper bounds and distinguish it from worst cases.
en.Slide 2: The upper bound of an algorithm indicates the upper or highest growth rate that the algorithm can have for a problem of size $n$.
en.Slide 3: The sequencial search algorithm accepts as its input an array of $n$ keys and the target key $k$ to search for.
en.Slide 4: So what is the upper bound of the sequencial search algorithm?
en.Slide 5: Do you think this is the correct way to ask this question?
en.Slide 6: Remember that there are three input cases that affect the running time of sequencial search.
en.Slide 7: 1- When the target ket $k$ is located at the first position in the input array.
en.Slide 8: 2- When the target ket $k$ is located at the last position in the input array.
en.Slide 9: 3- When the target key $k$ is located at the middle position in the input array.
en.Slide 10: The first case is the best case of the algorithm, since only a single element is investigated. $T(n) = 1$
en.Slide 11: Accordingly, the highest growth rate (upper bound) of the algorithm in the best case is $O(1)$.
en.Slide 12: The second case is the worst case of the algorithm, since $n$ elements are investigated. $T(n) = n$
en.Slide 13: Accordingly, the highest growth rate (upper bound) of the algorithm in the worst case is $O(n)$.
en.Slide 14: The third case is the average case of the algorithm, since $\lceil\frac{n}{2}\rceil$ elements are investigated. $T(n) = \frac{1}{2}n$
en.Slide 15: Accordingly, the highest growth rate (upper bound) of the algorithm in the average case is also $O(n)$ since we ignore constant terms.
en.Slide 16:
Accordingly, the correct way to ask the question should be :

What is the upper bound of sequencial search in the best/average/worst case?
